1.learning_goal: Foundations of AI: In this unit, students will build a practical understanding of what AI is and how it differs from traditional software, trace key milestones from rule-based to data-driven and modern statistical approaches (ML, DL, LLMs), distinguish symbolic vs statistical and narrow vs general AI in real-world scenarios, and apply basic Python, NumPy, and Pandas tools to load, inspect, filter, group, and enrich real datasets while connecting AI capabilities and limitations to data quality and societal impact.

chapters.title: Foundations of Artificial Intelligence
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will build a practical understanding of what AI is, how it evolved from rule-based systems to data-driven approaches, and how it differs from traditional software. Through hands-on activities, they will learn to recognize AI in everyday scenarios, distinguish rule-based from data-driven systems, and explain how rules and data shape an AI system’s behavior.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What Is Artificial Intelligence?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Artificial Intelligence in practical, non-sci-fi terms; Identify what makes a system “intelligent” in practice; Distinguish AI systems from traditional software

lessons.title: A Short History of AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe how early AI systems were built; Explain why early AI relied on rules and logic; Identify what changed when data became central

lessons.title: Rule-Based AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define rule-based (symbolic) AI; Explain how rules are written and applied; Identify strengths and limitations of rule-based systems

lessons.title: Data-Driven AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define data-driven (statistical) AI; Explain how data replaces explicit rules; Describe why data-driven systems scale better

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to distinguish AI systems from traditional software in everyday scenarios. Output: A completed worksheet where each scenario is labeled as “AI” or “not AI” with a short justification.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: AI Timeline Cards
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to place key AI milestones on a simple timeline and explain what changed at each step. Output: An ordered list or set of “timeline cards” with dates, event names, and one-sentence explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Rule-Based vs Data-Driven Sorting
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to clearly differentiate rule-based AI from data-driven AI using practical examples. Output: A table where example systems are classified as “rule-based,” “data-driven,” or “mixed,” with reasoning.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: If–Then Rules Lab
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to write clear, simple IF–THEN rules and explain how they control a rule-based system. Output: A small set of written rules for a toy “virtual assistant” that shows how decisions are made step by step.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Data-Driven Thinking
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to describe how changing data (not rules) can change an AI system’s behavior. Output: A short written analysis comparing outcomes for the same “AI system” under different data conditions.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Foundations of Modern AI
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, you will build a clear conceptual map of how modern AI works by contrasting symbolic and statistical approaches, narrow and general AI, and ML, DL, and LLMs. You will apply these ideas to real-world systems, your daily life, and data-quality scenarios so you can describe, classify, and critically discuss AI in practice.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Symbolic vs Statistical AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clearly distinguish symbolic AI from statistical AI; Compare how each approach handles complexity; Identify which approach powers most modern AI systems

lessons.title: Narrow AI vs General AI
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define Narrow AI using real-world examples; Define General AI conceptually and explain why it does not exist today; Correct common misconceptions about AI capabilities

lessons.title: ML, DL, and LLMs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and LLMs; Explain how these approaches relate to statistical AI; Use correct terminology when describing modern systems

lessons.title: AI in the Real World
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify real-world applications of AI across industries; Describe what type of data these systems rely on; Explain why AI behavior depends on data quality

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Symbolic vs Statistical Match-Up
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to match real-world systems to symbolic or statistical AI approaches and justify your choice. Output: A completed matching table linking example systems to “symbolic,” “statistical,” or “hybrid” with explanations.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Narrow vs General AI Scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to identify whether a described system is narrow AI, an unrealistic “general AI,” or pure science fiction. Output: A categorized list of scenarios labeled as “narrow AI,” “general AI idea,” or “sci-fi,” with one-sentence notes.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: ML, DL, and LLM Sorting Game
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to correctly label examples as Machine Learning, Deep Learning, or LLM-based and explain the differences. Output: A sorted list of example applications under three headings (ML, DL, LLMs) with brief justifications.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: AI in Daily Life Map
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to identify AI uses in your own day-to-day life and describe what data they rely on. Output: A simple “AI in my day” map listing at least 5 touchpoints, each with the type of AI and data used.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Data Quality Detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to analyze short case descriptions to identify how data quality can shape or distort AI behavior. Output: A set of annotated case snippets where you highlight data issues (bias, missing data, noise) and likely effects.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Working with Real Data in Python
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn how to responsibly apply AI concepts while using Python’s data toolbox—core Python, NumPy, and Pandas—to load, inspect, and reason about real-world datasets. They will practice distinguishing DataFrames from Series, verifying data imports, identifying basic data issues, and connecting AI limitations and societal impacts to concrete data analysis tasks.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: AI Limits and Responsibility
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify common limitations of AI systems; Explain why AI systems can fail or behave unexpectedly; Describe, at a high level, why AI impacts society

lessons.title: Python’s Data Toolbox
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain Python’s role in data analysis workflows; Distinguish Python libraries from core Python language features; Identify when to use Pandas versus NumPy

lessons.title: DataFrames and Series
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DataFrame and Series using tabular data examples; Explain how rows and columns map to DataFrame structure; Navigate and inspect basic DataFrame components

lessons.title: Loading Real Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load CSV data into a Pandas DataFrame; Verify that data loaded correctly using inspection methods; Identify basic issues immediately after loading data

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe orders DataFrame
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to load a small CSV of cafe orders into Pandas and inspect its basic structure with DataFrames and Series. Output: A Python script that loads a cafe_orders.csv file and prints info(), head(), and basic column summaries.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings DataFrame
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to distinguish between DataFrames and Series by exploring a movie ratings dataset in Python. Output: A Python script that loads movie_ratings.csv, selects individual Series, and prints their types and sample values.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Weather data loader
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to reliably load CSV weather data and verify that it imported correctly using Pandas inspection methods. Output: A Python script that reads weather.csv, prints shape, dtypes, sample rows, and flags obvious loading issues.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: AI survey analysis starter
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to connect AI limitations and responsibility concepts to a real dataset by inspecting an AI-opinion survey in Pandas. Output: A Python script that loads ai_survey.csv and prints focused views (selected columns, value_counts) for interpretation.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: NumPy vs Pandas toolbox
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to decide when to use core Python, NumPy, or Pandas for basic data tasks in a small analysis script. Output: A Python script that performs the same simple operations (averages, element-wise math, tabular inspection) using lists, NumPy arrays, and a Pandas DataFrame for comparison.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Exploring and Transforming Data with Pandas
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to inspect, select, filter, group, and transform tabular datasets using Pandas, and to explain your analysis in clear, plain language. Practice these skills through realistic mini-projects that involve reading data carefully, creating derived columns, and producing simple yet meaningful summaries.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Reading Data Carefully
lessons.learning_outcomes: Inspect datasets to understand structure and content; Identify potential data issues by scanning rows and columns; Formulate simple questions about what the data represents

lessons.title: Selecting and Filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Select specific columns from a DataFrame intentionally; Filter rows using logical conditions; Explain filtering logic clearly in plain language

lessons.title: Grouping Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Group data by categorical features using Pandas; Apply basic aggregations such as mean and count; Interpret grouped results in terms of real-world meaning

lessons.title: Derived Columns
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create new columns derived from existing data; Explain why derived columns can make data more useful; Verify correctness of newly created columns

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app user data scan
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to carefully inspect a music app user activity dataset to understand its structure and potential issues. Output: A Python script that loads music_users.csv and prints targeted inspections (head, sample rows, column descriptions, simple counts) with brief comments.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker filtering
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to select and filter DataFrame columns and rows to answer simple questions about fitness tracker data. Output: A Python script that loads fitness_data.csv and prints filtered subsets such as “steps over 10,000” or “workouts this week.”

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store grouping
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to group e-commerce order data by categories and compute simple aggregations like counts and averages. Output: A Python script that loads store_orders.csv and prints grouped summaries such as orders per category and average order value per customer segment.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Ride share grouping and filters
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to combine grouping and filtering to interpret ride-share data by city, time of day, and ride type. Output: A Python script that loads rides.csv and prints filtered and grouped tables such as “average fare by city and ride type during peak hours.”

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Food delivery derived columns
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will be able to create and verify new derived columns that make a food delivery dataset more useful for analysis. Output: A Python script that loads deliveries.csv, adds columns like delivery_duration_minutes and tip_percentage, and prints checks confirming their correctness.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

2.learning_goal: Foundations of EDA: In this unit, students will clean and structure real-world datasets (fixing data types, inspecting outliers, filtering, and grouping), build core exploratory data analysis skills (EDA concepts, variable types, first plots, patterns vs anomalies), and interpret distributions, averages, variability, and relationships (univariate, bivariate, and simple multivariate) to draw careful, well‑reasoned insights without over‑stating conclusions.

chapters.title: From Messy Tables to Meaningful Insights
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to clean and prepare real-world datasets by fixing data types, investigating outliers, applying purposeful filters, and using grouping to reveal patterns. Practice building a simple, end‑to‑end mini‑pipeline that turns raw data into clear, interpretable insights.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Fixing Data Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Detect columns with incorrect data types; Convert data types to enable proper analysis; Explain why correct data types are essential

lessons.title: Detecting and Understanding Outliers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify outliers using simple numerical and visual methods; Distinguish between meaningful outliers and problematic outliers; Explain why outliers should be investigated, not automatically removed

lessons.title: Filtering with Purpose
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply filters based on meaningful conditions; Explain why specific filters are applied; Validate that filtering produced expected results

lessons.title: Grouping for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping to compare categories in data; Interpret aggregated values meaningfully; Identify patterns revealed through grouping

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe sales data cleanup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice detecting and fixing incorrect data types in a small cafe sales dataset and explain why each change is needed. Output: A cleaned DataFrame where dates, prices, and quantities have correct data types ready for analysis.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app outlier hunt
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify and visualize outliers in a music streaming dataset (e.g., play counts, session lengths) and decide which are meaningful vs problematic. Output: A notebook/cell output that highlights suspected outliers with simple plots and a short written classification (meaningful vs problematic).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online shop filtering with purpose
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply purposeful filters on an e-commerce orders dataset to answer concrete questions (e.g., high-value orders, specific time periods) and verify results. Output: Filtered views/tables that match clearly stated conditions and a short text check confirming that the filters behaved as expected.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie ratings grouping for insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use grouping and aggregation on a movie ratings dataset to compare categories (e.g., genre, age group) and interpret the patterns revealed. Output: Grouped summary tables (e.g., average rating by genre) and a short interpretation of at least two observed patterns.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Data cleaning mini‑pipeline
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine data type fixing, outlier inspection, purposeful filtering, and grouping into a simple end‑to‑end analysis on a restaurant orders dataset. Output: A mini analysis report (code + short text) that cleans the data, flags outliers, filters to a target subset, and shows grouped insights (e.g., revenue by dish or time of day).

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Exploratory Data Analysis Foundations
chapters.learning_goals: Build a practical understanding of exploratory data analysis (EDA), from clarifying questions and choosing appropriate plots to identifying patterns, anomalies, and data types. Learn to conduct and clearly document EDA in a way that is distinct from modeling and final conclusions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What EDA Really Means
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define exploratory data analysis in clear, practical terms; Explain the goals of EDA before modeling or decisions; Distinguish EDA from final conclusions

lessons.title: First Plots for Insight
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create basic plots using matplotlib; Choose plot types appropriate to specific questions; Interpret plots to describe trends and patterns

lessons.title: Patterns and Anomalies
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify patterns emerging from data exploration; Detect anomalies and unusual values; Explain findings clearly without over-interpreting

lessons.title: Data Types & “What am I analyzing?”
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish numerical vs categorical variables; Identify whether a question is univariate or relationship-based; Understand that choosing appropriate summary statistics and visualizations is based on data type and get an overview of main techniques according to data type

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: EDA concepts check
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish clearly between EDA, final conclusions, and modeling by answering conceptual questions, sorting statements, and short explanations. Output: A completed written exercise where statements are categorized (EDA vs conclusion vs modeling) and key EDA goals are articulated in your own words.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Ride‑sharing first plots
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create basic matplotlib plots (histograms, bar charts, line plots) on a ride‑sharing dataset and choose appropriate plot types for different questions. Output: A set of plots (e.g., rides per hour, average fare by day) with brief captions explaining what each plot shows.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Patterns and anomalies in retail
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explore a retail sales dataset to identify visible patterns (e.g., weekly seasonality) and anomalies (e.g., sudden spikes or drops) and describe them without over‑interpreting. Output: A few simple visualizations plus a short written summary highlighting at least two patterns and two anomalies.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Data type and question matcher
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice classifying variables as numerical or categorical and labeling questions as univariate or relationship‑based, then match each to suitable summaries and plots. Output: A filled‑in table or notes mapping variables/questions to “numeric/categorical,” “univariate/bivariate,” and “recommended summary/visualization.”

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: EDA checklist on a movie dataset
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply an EDA mini‑checklist to a movie dataset, from defining questions to choosing plots, summarizing findings, and clearly separating exploration from conclusions. Output: A short EDA notebook section with chosen questions, plots, basic summaries, and a clearly labeled “exploration notes” section (not final conclusions).

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Understanding Distributions and Averages
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to interpret distributions beyond single summary numbers, choose appropriate measures of center (mean vs median), and reason intuitively about variability, randomness, and noise. Apply these ideas to real‑world style datasets (scores, income, traffic, housing) to distinguish meaningful patterns from misleading ones.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Distributions - Looking beyond single numbers
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain what a distribution represents; Interpret basic distribution shape using a histogram or bar chart; Describe why summary statistics alone can be misleading without distribution context

lessons.title: Mean vs Median - Choosing the right “average”
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define mean and median with practical examples; Select mean vs median depending on skew and outliers; Explain how outliers can distort the mean and affect interpretation

lessons.title: Variability & Standard Deviation (Intuition)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain variability as how spread out values are; Interpret standard deviation at an intuitive level in terms of high vs low spread; Compare two datasets and infer which has more variability

lessons.title: Randomness, Noise & Why patterns can be misleading
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define randomness and noise in real datasets; Recognize when a pattern may be caused by noise rather than signal; Explain why repeated measurements or samples may lead to different results

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Game scores distributions
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use histograms and bar charts on game score data to interpret distribution shapes and explain why a single summary statistic can be misleading. Output: Plots of score distributions plus a brief comparison showing how distributions with similar means can look very different.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Income mean vs median
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare mean and median on skewed income‑like data with outliers and decide which “average” better represents the typical value in each scenario. Output: A small table of mean/median values for different subsets and a short justification for choosing one measure over the other.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Exam score variability
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare variability between two or more exam score datasets using intuitive standard deviation concepts and explain which group is more consistent. Output: Calculated basic spread metrics (e.g., standard deviation) and a short explanation of which dataset is more/less variable and why that matters.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Randomness in website traffic
lessons.learning_outcomes: Simulate or inspect day‑to‑day website traffic data to distinguish random noise from meaningful patterns and explain why repeated samples differ. Output: Simple time‑series plots or simulated runs showing fluctuating values, with annotations or notes explaining which fluctuations are likely noise.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Distributions and averages review
lessons.learning_outcomes: Integrate distributions, mean vs median, and variability by analyzing a small housing price dataset and explaining how shape, center, and spread interact. Output: A concise mini‑report with plots and metrics that contrasts at least two neighborhoods or segments in terms of distribution shape, typical value, and variability.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking in Relationships: From Correlation to Multivariate Views
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to explore and interpret relationships between variables using bivariate and multivariate thinking, including appropriate visualizations and correlation measures. Build intuition about why correlation does not imply causation and how adding more variables changes insights, preparing you to reason about features and modeling decisions.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Bivariate Thinking - Relationships between two variables
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify when a question requires bivariate analysis; Choose an appropriate visualization such as a scatter plot for numeric-numeric or a box plot for categorical-numeric; Describe what it means for two variables to move together at an intuitive level

lessons.title: Correlation - Pearson vs Spearman (High level)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define correlation and interpret positive vs negative correlation; Differentiate Pearson correlation from Spearman correlation at a high level; Explain when Spearman may be more appropriate than Pearson

lessons.title: Correlation ≠ Causation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why correlation does not imply causation; Identify common pitfalls such as confounders and reverse causality conceptually; Propose ways to reduce wrong conclusions, such as checking other variables or using domain reasoning

lessons.title: Multivariate Intuition - When relationships change
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why adding a third variable can change an observed relationship; Describe controlling for another variable conceptually; Understand why multivariate thinking connects to feature selection and ML modeling decisions at a high level

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Study time vs test score
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use scatter plots to examine the relationship between study time and test scores and describe intuitively what it means for the variables to move together. Output: A scatter plot (optionally with a simple trend line) and a brief explanation of whether there appears to be a positive, negative, or no clear relationship.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Correlation explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compute and interpret Pearson and Spearman correlations on a small numeric dataset (e.g., heights and rankings) and decide when each is more appropriate. Output: A table of Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients for a few variable pairs and short text interpreting their magnitude and differences.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Correlation vs causation quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze short story scenarios where two variables are correlated, identify possible confounders or reverse causality, and explain why causation cannot be claimed. Output: Written answers labeling each scenario as “correlation only” with proposed confounders or alternative explanations.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Multivariate movie ratings
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explore how the relationship between movie length and rating changes when controlling for a third variable (e.g., genre or age group) to build multivariate intuition. Output: Side‑by‑side plots or grouped summaries (e.g., scatter by genre color or boxplots by length category within genre) plus a short explanation of how the relationship differs across groups.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Relationship patterns overview
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine bivariate and multivariate thinking by examining a small dataset with several variables, sketching which pairs are related, and hypothesizing which might matter most in a future model. Output: A simple “relationship map” (notes or diagram) plus a few prioritized variable pairs with brief justifications based on observed plots and correlations.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges
